Indeed, the continuity of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] is not made easy except by avoiding the world [dunya] and its desires, and restricting oneself from it to the measure of necessity. And that is not perfected except by immersing the times of night and day in the duties of remembrances and contemplations. And the soul [nafs], due to what it is created upon of weariness and boredom, does not persevere with a single mode of the means that aid in remembrance and contemplation. Rather, if it is returned to a single pattern, it displays boredom and a sense of burden. And from the necessity of being gentle with it is to refresh it by shifting from one mode to another and from one type to another according to each time, so that its pleasure is increased by the transition, its desire is magnified by the pleasure, and its constancy endures by the endurance of the desire. Therefore, the litanies [awrad] are divided into a varied division, and remembrance and contemplation should encompass all times or most of them. For the soul, by its nature, is inclined to the pleasures of the world. So if the servant spends half his times on the arrangements and permissible desires of the world, and the other half on acts of worship, the side of inclination to the world is weighted, because it agrees with his nature, since the time is equal. How then can they be balanced when the nature gives weight to one of them? For the outward and inward cooperate in the matters of the world, and the heart [qalb] becomes pure and single-minded in seeking it. As for being turned back to acts of worship, it is contrived, and the sincerity [ikhlas] of the heart and its presence therein is not sound except at some times. So whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse his times in obedience. And whoever wishes for the scale of his good deeds to be weighted and the balances of his goodness to be heavy, let him occupy most of his times in obedience. If he mixes a righteous deed with another evil one, then his affair is perilous. But hope is not cut off, and pardon from the generosity of Allah is awaited. Perhaps Allah, the Exalted, will forgive him by His bounty and generosity. This is what has been unveiled to the observers by the light of insight [basira]. If you are not of its people, then look to the address of Allah, the Exalted, to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith [iman]. For Allah, the Exalted, has said: *"And glorify the praise of your Lord when you rise [from sleep], and at night glorify Him, and at the setting of the stars."* So He made clear that the purpose of the sun and moon running in a precise, ordered system, and of the creation of shadow and light and the stars, is not to seek help through them in the matters of the world, but rather to know by them the measures of times so that one may occupy them with acts of obedience and trade for the Abode of the Hereafter [akhira].
